Valentina Rita Scotti discusses the impact of the principle of equality in the Charters approved in Canada since the 1867 British North American Act. The essay assesses whether intersectionality represents for Aboriginal  women a source of double discrimination. The 1840  Act  of the Union  of Canada was  neutral as  as  it entered into force. Women were denied the right to vote by establishing it only for British (or naturalized) males over 21 years old. World War I partially changed societal behaviour, and women’s participation in the military effort was rewarded with a recognition of the vote in some Provinces.  In 1920 the Dominion Elections Act was amended to recognise  all  Canadians,  male  or female,  over  21 as  eligible  voters  in federal elections. In 1929 a specific decision of the Privy Council was needed to recognise women’s voting eligibility. In spite of this recognition of gender equality, women belonging  to minorities continued to be  considered  minors for a long time.  The Canadian Bill of Rights recognized that rights should be protected ‘without discrimination by reason of race, national origin, colour, religion or sex’ Despite the recognition of rights and the enactment of laws (almost) equalising women to men in the field of private law, sex still was not fully  conceived  of  possible discrimination.  The Supreme Court’s adjudication on women's rights has proved quite beneficial, in opposition to the original patriarchal approach of the Canadian Supreme Court. In 1876 British common law rulings stated  ‘women  are  persons  in matters  of  pains, but are not persons in matters of rights and privileges’, it was the Privy Council which finally intervened in recognizing  women as persons in the legal sense.
